Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Wildfire, Wine, and Water Quality: Immediate Changes to Biogeochemical and Hydrological Flows from Vineyards After the Northern California Fires
Award.AbstractNarration:
In early October 2017, multiple wildfires ignited across Northern California's (CA) premier winegrowing region, incinerating vineyards and neighboring communities, with as yet unknown consequences for hydrology, biogeochemical cycling, water quality, and human and ecosystem health. This is a particularly important region to study the impacts of wildfire, as changes to soils and hydrology will likely affect the fate of the large reactive sulfur (S) loads applied to vineyards each year for powdery mildew control. Widespread S use may have consequences for adjacent ecosystems similar to those of inadvertent atmospheric S deposition (i.e., 'acid rain'), such as stimulating production of methylmercury, a potent neurotoxin. Given that wildfire may accelerate mobilization of S and other materials to adjacent aquatic ecosystems, the need to pursue this research has now become urgent. The study will address the immediate effects of wildfire on hydrological flow paths and mobilization of S from vineyards to streams. The project team will instrument a burned and unburned vineyard catchment with subsurface soil water and surface water (runoff and stream) collectors. They will conduct field observations of hydrologic flows during the first large rain events of the wet season to quantify mobilized S, C, and sediment, perform a laboratory experiment to determine chemical losses from burned and unburned soils over time, and develop methods to trace S in the environment. This study will provide a dataset critical for proceeding with longer-term efforts to develop field studies, experiments, and models to elucidate the ultimate fates and consequences of agricultural S use at the basin scale - a new area of research to understand human manipulation of the S cycle. This one-year project will be led by a female assistant professor, train a female graduate student, and provide data that will be important for farmers and other stakeholders. The research group will communicate their findings broadly in multiple workshops within the study region.

The goal of this one-year field- and laboratory-based study is to provide an important dataset detailing the effects of recent, widespread wildfire on mobilization of agricultural sulfur (S) from vineyards to streams in the North Coast California winegrowing region. These data are a critical baseline to capture prior to initiating a new wave of research: determining the unintended consequences of high S applications in regional agricultural systems. The biogeochemical and ecological effects of high S use may be similar to those of inadvertent atmospheric S deposition (i.e., "acid rain"), but they have not yet been studied in vineyards or other crop systems. In particular, agriculturally-derived S may stimulate production of methylmercury in aquatic ecosystems downgradient of source areas, threatening the health of humans and wildlife. This study will make the first measurements of S, carbon (C), and sediment mobilized from burned vineyards to streams during the onset of the rainy season, and develop new geochemical and isotopic methods for tracing agriculturally-derived S species in the environment. To this end, the project team will instrument a burned and an unburned vineyard catchment with runoff collectors, ISCO stream samplers, soil water samplers, and soil moisture sensors to quantify hydrological flow paths and assess their chemical composition. They will also conduct burned and unburned soil core leaching experiments to determine the evolution of chemical losses over the course of a simulated wet season. These activities will test two hypotheses: (1) If the heat input from fire has dramatically changed surface soil properties relative to unburned vineyards, moderate-to-high intensity rain events will cause surface runoff that rapidly (minutes to hours) transports S, C, and sediment from burned vineyards to streams, and (2) If surface runoff dominates the hydrologic response in burned vineyards, then mobilized S species will have a light isotopic value, reflecting minimal interaction with the soil matrix.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large, purposeful applications of reactive sulfur (S) are used in a variety of regional agricultural systems as a fertilizer, pH regulator, or fungicide. However, little is known about the fates, transport, and consequences of their use for local and adjacent ecosystems. Decades of research on the effects of acid rain have demonstrated that excess atmospheric S deposition can cause base cation losses, soil and surface water acidification, and mobilization of heavy metals in forested ecosystems; similar impacts may occur in and downgradient of crop lands where high S applications are used, but they have not been explored broadly. Napa Valley, California, is home to the premier winegrowing region in the United States. There, S is used ubiquitously as a fungicide, with average applications of 150 kg ha-1 yr-1, creating an ideal model system to explore the fates and consequences of agricultural S inputs.

Following the Northern California wildfires in October 2017, the investigators sought to determine how fire affects the fate and geochemical ?fingerprint? of applied S in the watershed. The major goals of this project were to: (1) evaluate the direct impacts of the Northern California wildfires on S and carbon (C) losses from soils in agricultural areas and non-agricultural areas (i.e., grasslands) using a laboratory simulated rainfall experiment, (2) develop methods for tracing agricultural S within watersheds, (3) determine whether or not wildfire affects the stable isotopic composition of S exported from agricultural source areas, and (4) provide important, baseline data for moving forward with investigating the biogeochemical and ecological consequences of high agricultural S inputs.

The research activities yielded several important results. Vineyard soils started with and lost more S (via leachate) than other soils following a simulated rainfall season, indicating that they had the greatest stored sulfate and it was rapidly transported. In addition, burned vineyard soils lost more dissolved organic C (DOC) than other soils (unburned vineyard or burned/unburned grassland), suggesting that wildfire stimulated loss of stored C from agricultural soils. Finally, the S stable isotopic composition of soil leachates from burned and unburned vineyards was virtually the same and unique relative to that of non-agricultural areas, providing evidence that S stable isotopes can be used to trace agricultural S through complex watersheds. However, measurement of the S stable isotopic composition of sulfate in stream water demonstrated that streams draining burned catchments without vineyards had a similar isotopic ?fingerprint? to that of streams draining catchments with vineyards; while waters draining vineyards have enriched δ34S due to microbial processes, wildfire may preferentially remove the lighter isotope (32S) from burned soils, creating a similarly enriched isotopic signal. In future work, it will be important to understand the contribution of different land covers if wildfire has occurred, as this disturbance can complicate the ability to identify agricultural S isotopically within complex watersheds.

The Broader Impacts components of the research included: (1) disseminating results at a meeting of 30 stakeholders and two national conferences, (2) training one female graduate student and two undergraduate students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields, (3) bringing a graduate class to the field sites to conduct research in working lands, and (4) reporting results to representatives from the California Department of Pesticide Regulation to inform surface water monitoring programs in the future. In addition, the award provided an early career female investigator with important datasets to stimulate further study of the fate and consequences of high S use in the environment by her research group.
